GameDBLocalizedString.Text: The patient has a high red blood cell count.
The patient's hemoglobin is too high.

Bone marrow biopsy: significant fibrosis, marked proliferation of hematopoietic cells of all lineages, reduced adipose tissue, and relatively obvious megakaryocyte proliferation. The granulocyte to erythroblast ratio is often decreased. Iron staining shows reduced storage iron.
Bone marrow biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of primary myelofibrosis.
Flow cytometry: Red blood cells are deficient in CD59.
Peripheral blood clonal B-lymphocytes â‰¥5x10^9/L, cell morphology similar to mature small lymphocytes, with a small number of immature or atypical lymphocytes, and smudge cells are visible.
Typical Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells were found in the bone marrow, indicating tumor invasion of the bone marrow.
Tissue biopsy revealed typical Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells.
Biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of Mantle Cell Lymphoma.
Biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma.
Biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of Follicular Lymphoma.
Bone marrow aspirate: Increased clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow.
The level of uric acid in the blood is too high.
Hypercalcemia is a common electrolyte disorder.

Based on progressively worsening symptoms and comparison of recent blood test results, the patient is suspected of having a hemolytic crisis. Hemolytic crisis (HC) can present with different clinical manifestations depending on various triggers and disease stages, but it is fundamentally an acute hemolysis caused by massive destruction of red blood cells and a sharp drop in hemoglobin over a short period.
The spleen is palpable below the costal margin, suggesting splenomegaly.
Bone marrow aspirate: Bone marrow is hypercellular or markedly hypercellular, showing dyspoiesis.
Bone marrow aspirate: Significant erythroid hyperplasia, positive iron stain, and increased sideroblasts.
Hemoglobin electrophoresis revealed abnormal hemoglobin associated with thalassemia.
Bone marrow cytochemistry, immunology, cytogenetics, and molecular biology tests confirmed the subtype as Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL).
Bone marrow cytochemistry, immunology, cytogenetics, and molecular biology tests confirmed the subtype as Hairy Cell Leukemia (HCL).
Bone marrow cytochemistry, immunology, cytogenetics, and molecular biology tests confirmed the subtype as Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML).
Bone marrow cytochemistry, immunology, cytogenetics, and molecular biology tests confirmed the subtype as Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML).
Bone marrow cytochemistry, immunology, cytogenetics, and molecular biology tests confirmed the subtype as Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL).

When leukemia cells involve the central nervous system and present with symptoms such as headache, nausea, vomiting, neck stiffness, convulsions, coma, and cranial nerve damage, it is called Central Nervous System Leukemia (CNSL).

Bone marrow aspirate shows: active or markedly active proliferation of nucleated marrow cells; predominantly erythroid hyperplasia, with no significant abnormalities in granulocytic or megakaryocytic lineages; the erythroid series is dominated by intermediate and late normoblasts, which are small in size, with dense nuclear chromatin, scanty cytoplasm, irregular morphology, and show signs of poor hemoglobinization ("nuclear-cytoplasmic asynchrony"). No significant changes in the granulocytic and megakaryocytic lineages.

Bone marrow aspirate shows: active or markedly active proliferation of marrow, with significant erythroid hyperplasia. Cells of all lineages exhibit megaloblastic changes (large cell body, delayed nuclear development with normal cytoplasmic development, "nuclear-cytoplasmic asynchrony"), most prominently in the erythroid series. Megaloblastic changes in granulocytes are more pronounced in metamyelocytes and band forms. Megakaryocytes are increased in number, enlarged in size, and hypersegmented. Bone marrow iron staining is increased.

Normocytic anemia refers to MCV 80-100 fl and MCHC 32-35% (MCV, mean corpuscular volume; MCHC, mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration). Common causes include acute blood loss anemia, aplastic anemia, certain hemolytic anemias, and anemia caused by endocrine, liver, or kidney diseases. Anemia is a syndrome caused by various factors leading to a decrease in the amount of hemoglobin, red blood cell count, and red blood cell volume per unit volume of peripheral blood, falling below the lower limit of the normal range, resulting in insufficient oxygen transport to tissues. Due to the complexity of measuring red blood cell volume, it is clinically defined as a peripheral blood hemoglobin concentration lower than the normal standard for the patient's age, sex, and region. Based on cell morphology, anemia can be classified into microcytic hypochromic anemia, normocytic anemia, and macrocytic anemia.

Microcytic hypochromic anemia refers to MCV < 80 fl and MCHC < 32% (MCV, mean corpuscular volume; MCHC, mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration). Common causes include iron deficiency anemia, sideroblastic anemia, and thalassemia. Anemia is a syndrome caused by various factors leading to a decrease in the amount of hemoglobin, red blood cell count, and red blood cell volume per unit volume of peripheral blood, falling below the lower limit of the normal range, resulting in insufficient oxygen transport to tissues. Due to the complexity of measuring red blood cell volume, it is clinically defined as a peripheral blood hemoglobin concentration lower than the normal standard for the patient's age, sex, and region. Based on cell morphology, anemia can be classified into microcytic hypochromic anemia, normocytic anemia, and macrocytic anemia.

Macrocytic anemia refers to MCV > 100 fl and MCHC 32-35% (MCV, mean corpuscular volume; MCHC, mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration). Common causes include megaloblastic anemia, hemolytic anemia with significant reticulocytosis, myelodysplastic syndrome, and liver diseases. Anemia is a syndrome caused by various factors leading to a decrease in the amount of hemoglobin, red blood cell count, and red blood cell volume per unit volume of peripheral blood, falling below the lower limit of the normal range, resulting in insufficient oxygen transport to tissues. Due to the complexity of measuring red blood cell volume, it is clinically defined as a peripheral blood hemoglobin concentration lower than the normal standard for the patient's age, sex, and region. Based on cell morphology, anemia can be classified into microcytic hypochromic anemia, normocytic anemia, and macrocytic anemia.
Serum ferritin test indicates iron deficiency.
Serum vitamin B12 test indicates vitamin B12 deficiency.
Serum folate test indicates folate deficiency.

Bone marrow aspirate shows: hypocellularity or severe hypocellularity in multiple sites (different planes); empty spicules, increased proportion of non-hematopoietic cells (lymphocytes, reticular cells, plasma cells, mast cells, etc.); markedly reduced or absent megakaryocytes; both erythroid and granulocytic lineages are markedly reduced. Suggestive of aplastic anemia.
An increased reticulocyte count reflects vigorous erythroid proliferation in the bone marrow, commonly seen in hemolytic anemia.
A decreased reticulocyte count reflects reduced bone marrow hematopoietic function, commonly seen in aplastic anemia or pure red cell aplasia.
The patient feels severe bone pain.
von Willebrand factor antigen test result suggests von Willebrand disease.
Decreased factor VIII activity suggests Hemophilia A.
Decreased factor IX activity suggests Hemophilia B.

Bone marrow aspirate: Normal erythroid and myeloid hematopoiesis, normal or increased number of megakaryocytes, but platelet-producing megakaryocytes are significantly reduced or absent. Morphologically, megakaryocytes show signs of maturation arrest, such as increased size, mononuclear forms, scanty cytoplasm, and lack of granules, with no signs of dyspoiesis.
Bone marrow aspirate: Good marrow cellularity, but the erythroid series is markedly reduced or absent, with other lineages being largely normal.
